review.title: Connotation Frames: A Data-Driven Investigation
review.abstract: Through a choice of a predicate (e.g., "violate"), a writer can convey subtle sentiments and value judgements toward the arguments of a verb (e.g., projecting the agent as an "antagonist" and the theme as a "victim"). We introduce connotation frames to encode the rich dimensions of implied sentiment, value judgements, and effect evaluation as typed relations that these choices influence, and propose a factor graph formulation that captures the inter-play among different types of connotative relations at the lexicon-level. Experimental results confirm that our model is effective in predicting connotative sentiments compared to strong baselines and existing sentiment lexicons.
histories: 11 pages, published in Proceedings of ACL 2016

metadata.title: Connotation Frames: A Data-Driven Investigation

sections.text: We introduce connotation frameworks as representational formalism to organize these rich dimensions of connotation through typewritten relationships. First, we examine the feasibility of obtaining connotation frameworks through crowdsourcing experiments. Then, we present models to predict the connotation frameworks of verb predicates based on their distribution word representations and the interaction between different types of connotation relationships. Empirical results confirm that connotation frameworks can be generated from different data sources that reflect how people use language and lead to the connotation meanings. We conclude with analytical results that demonstrate the potential use of connotation frameworks to analyze subtle distortions in online news media.

sections.heading: 2 Connotation Frame
sections.text: Considering a predicate v, we define a connotation frame F (v) as a collection of typed relationships and their polarity assignments: (i) perspective Pv (xi → xj): whether the predicate v implies a targeted sensation from the entity xi to the entity xj, (ii) value Vv (xi): whether xi is assumed to be valuable by the predicate v, (iii) effect Ev (xi): whether the event indicated by the predicate v is good or bad for the entity xi, and (iv) state of mind Sv (xi): the probable state of mind of the entity xi as a result of the event. We assume that each typed relationship can have one of the three connotation relations, positive, negative, negative or neutral. Our goal in this essay is to focus on the general connotation of the predicate xi considered from the context.

sections.heading: 2.1 Data-driven Motivation
sections.text: Since the meaning of language is ultimately contextual, the exact connotation will vary depending on the context of each utterance. sections.heading: 3 Modeling Connotation Frames
sections.text: Our task is essentially that of lexicon induction (Akkaya et al., 2009; Feng et al., 2013), inducing the connotation frames of hitherto invisible verbs. From each verb predicate, we conclude a connotation frame consisting of 9 relationship aspects, which stand for: perspective {P (w → t), P (w → a), P (a → t), effect {E (t), value {V (t), V (a)} and state of mind {S (t), S (a)} polarities, whereby w, a, t each denotes the writer, the agent and the topic. We propose two models: an aspect-level model, which makes the prediction of each typed relationship independent of the distribution representation of the context in which the predicate usually appears (§ 3.1), and a frame-level model, which makes prediction of the connotation collectively taking into account 3.dynamic relations (§ 3.2).

sections.heading: 3.1 Aspect-Level
sections.text: For input, we use the 300-dimensional dependency-based word embedding of Levy and Goldberg (2014). For each aspect, there is a separate MaxEnt (Maximum Entropy) classifier, which is used to predict the name of that aspect on a given word embedding, which is treated as a 300-dimensional input vector for the classifier. MaxEnt classifiers learn their weights using LBFGS based on the training data examples by reweighting the samples to maximize the best average F1 value.

sections.heading: 5 Related Work
sections.text: Most previous work on sentiment lexicographies focused on the general polarity of words without taking into account their semantic arguments (Wilson et al., 2005; Baccianella et al., 2010; Wiebe et al., 2005; Velikovich et al., 2010b; Kaji and Kitsuregawa, 2007; Kamps et al., 2004; Takamura et al., 2005; Adreevskaia and Bergler, 2006) Several recent studies have begun to draw inspiration from more specific and nuanced aspects of feeling such as connotation (Feng et al., 2013), good and bad effects (Choi and Wiebe, 2014) and evoked sentiment (Mohammad and Turney, 2010). Drawing inspiration from them, we present connotation frames as a unifying framework of representation to encode the rich dimensions of implied feelings, anticipate value components, and effect theory, and represent a factoring formulation that describes the interplay of different types and relationships.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we present a novel system of connotation frames that defines a set of implicit feelings and presupposed facts for a predicate. Our work also empirically investigates different methods of inducing and modelling these connotation frames, taking into account the interaction between relationships within frames. Our work proposes new research options for learning connotation frames and applying them to a deeper understanding of social and political discourse. All connotation frames and annotations learned are available at http: / / homes.cs.washington.edu / ˜ hrashkin / connframe.html.

metadata.abstractText: Through a particular choice of a predicate (e.g., “x violated y”), a writer can subtly connote a range of implied sentiments and presupposed facts about the entities x and y: (1) writer’s perspective: projecting x as an “antagonist” and y as a “victim”, (2) entities’ perspective: y probably dislikes x, (3) effect: something bad happened to y, (4) value: y is something valuable, and (5) mental state: y is distressed by the event. We introduce connotation frames as a representation formalism to organize these rich dimensions of connotation using typed relations. First, we investigate the feasibility of obtaining connotative labels through crowdsourcing experiments. We then present models for predicting the connotation frames of verb predicates based on their distributional word representations and the interplay between different types of connotative relations. Empirical results confirm that connotation frames can be induced from various data sources that reflect how people use language and give rise to the connotative meanings. We conclude with analytical results that show the potential use of connotation frames for analyzing subtle biases in online news media.
